results.lead_paragraph: RUVEN AFANADOR As the photographer Ruven Afanador knows, taking someone's photograph is an act of intimacy. ''Somehow it's like a dance,'' he says. ''The person usually manages to arrive at the place where I'm pleased with it.'' His photographs of five grandes dames of Italian design (Page 150) are as playful and tough as the women themselves. Similar qualities can be found in his fashion photography (far left) and in his two books of tender portraits of powerful men: ''Sombra'' (Merrell) features classical dancers, while ''Torero'' (Edition Stemmle, above) is about bullfighters. So does the photographer have any desire to get up close and personal with a bull himself? ''No,'' he says with a laugh. More of Afanador's work is on view in the exhibit ''Seven'' at Forma in Milan.

results.abstract: About 100 members of Tripoli Rocketry Assn meet in Black Rock, Nev, desert for Indy 500 of rocketry; highlight of annual event is launching of rockets that teams have spent up to year making at cost of thousands of dollars; amateur rocketeers, about 6,000 nationwide, have had to contend with tougher restrictions from federal government and local fire marshals since Sept 11, and are involved in seven-year-old dispute with Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives over their use of propellant; photos (M)

headline.main: A Cult of Backyard Rocketeers Keeps the Solid Fuel Burning

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: BUREAU OF ALCOHOL, TOBACCO, FIREARMS AND EXPLOSIVES

results.snippet: Once a year, on a bleak, 400-square-mile dry lake bed, do-it-yourself rocket enthusiasts meet for the Indy 500 of rocketry.
results.lead_paragraph: Wedge Oldham, a 49-year-old software engineer from Los Angeles, finds nothing sweeter than spending a fall weekend in the Black Rock desert, barking rocket launching commands like ''Are we good to go?'' into the hot dusty wind. Nerves jangling, he awaits the moment when Carpe Diem, his homemade 18-foot-long rocket, hurls itself heavenward with 737 pounds of thrust, shockwaves -- or ''mach diamonds'' -- surging from its supersonic exhaust. With dazed exuberance he watches it recede into deep blue sky, and then, with the release of parachutes, gently drift four miles away, preserved for another flight.

results.abstract: First article in series Power Plays; about 40 percent of all electric customers have paid modestly lower prices over past decade since federal government opened electric-generating business to competition, but only because states imposed cuts, freezes and caps to insulate customers from initial price swings; last of rate protections expires in 2007, and customers could experience shock as utilities try to make up lost money; genuinely competitive market has not developed; some utilities buy electricity not from cheapest supplier but one owned by sister company; utilities pay each supplier highest price submitted in bidding if electricity is needed from more than one source; one-price system is intended to encourage investment in new power plants, which are costlier than old ones; map (L)

headline.main: COMPETITIVE ERA FAILS TO SHRINK ELECTRIC BILLS

results.snippet: A decade after the electricity business was opened to competition, the market has not produced a drop in prices.
results.lead_paragraph: A decade after competition was introduced in their industries, long-distance phone rates had fallen by half, air fares by more than a fourth and trucking rates by a fourth. But a decade after the federal government opened the business of generating electricity to competition, the market has produced no such decline. Instead, more rate increase requests are pending now than ever before, said Jim Owen, a spokesman for the Edison Electric Institute, the association for the investor-owned utilities that provide about 60 percent of the nation's power. The investor-owned electric utility industry published a June report entitled ''Why Are Electricity Prices Increasing?''

headline.main: From Bollywood to New York, a Tale of Lovers Lost and Found

results.snippet: This good-natured Bollywood musical is a romantic triangle set in New York. Personable stars partly make up for the excesses of the genre.
results.lead_paragraph: This good-natured Bollywood musical is a romantic triangle set in New York. Personable stars partly make up for the excesses of the genre.

results.abstract: Park named for astronaut Ronald E McNair, who died in Challenger disaster, opens in East Harlem; photo (M)

headline.main: Park Named for Astronaut Opens in Harlem

results.snippet: On the eve of what would have been his birthday, the Parks Department announced the opening of a park named for Ronald E. McNair, one of the astronauts who died aboard the Challenger space shuttle.
results.lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago the city's Parks Department fenced off a vacant lot in East Harlem and announced that it planned to build a park named for Ronald E. McNair, one of the astronauts who died aboard the Challenger space shuttle. For years nothing happened. The lot became an illegal dumping ground for contractors, who used it to dispose of building material, and at night as a safe haven for drug users, who would periodically cut through the chain-link fence on the perimeter.

headline.seo: The Wild Blue Yonder - Movies - Review

results.snippet: An artful mixture of carefully culled and originally produced material, Werner Herzog's “a science fiction fantasy” purports to tell the story of an alien species.
results.lead_paragraph: An artful mixture of carefully culled and originally produced material, Werner Herzog's “a science fiction fantasy” purports to tell the story of an alien species.

results.abstract: Iranians hail recent voyage of Anousheh Ansari, first woman to go into space as private explorer; she is Iranian-American businesswoman who founded company in Texas with her husband; Iranians openly admire her courage and her success; she reportedly paid $20 million for 10 days in space in Russian Soyuz spacecraft, including eight days at International Space Station; but some Iranians wonder why she did not use that money to help poor Iranians; she has responded by saying she could not solve Iran's problems by 'throwing money' at them as long as there are corrupt governments there; photos (M)
results.snippet: Iranians hailed the recent voyage of an Iranian-American woman into space, but not everyone is cheering for her.

multimedia.caption: Space Tourism
multimedia.credit: Anousheh Ansari became the first woman to go into space as an amateur astronaut and the fourth private space explorer to buy a ticket to visit the International Space Station.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Anousheh Ansari became the first woman to go into space as an amateur astronaut and the fourth private space explorer to buy a ticket to visit the International Space Station.

results.lead_paragraph: Iranians hailed the recent voyage of the first woman to go into space as a private explorer, an Iranian-American, with two jokes that circulated widely on cellphones. Muslim clerics, went the first, were refusing to look into the sky for the moon so that they could announce the beginning of Ramadan because they feared seeing the amateur astronaut without her veil.
